data.text: Index
Appendix 1: Initial Management of Patients with Parkinson's Disease who are
Nil by Mouth or who have swallowing difficulties
Table1: Management of Parkinson's disease patients with swallowing difficulties or
feeding tubes in situ
Table 2: Rotigotine conversion table if only on levodopa (with or without COMT
inhibitor) preparation
Table 3: Switching guidelines from a single oral dopamine agonist to Rotigotine
transdermal patch
Appendix 2: Parkinson's Medication available in Emergency Department Appendix 3: Preliminary Equality Analysis
Purpose

To be used by non-specialists to support prescribing, dispensing and administration of medicines for patients with Parkinson's disease with swallowing difficulties or a feeding tube in situ, whilst awaiting specialist review.
Scope
This guideline is for use in all patients who are receiving active treatment for Parkinson's disease who develop swallowing difficulties or have a feeding tube in situ.
It is the responsibility of the prescribing doctor to ensure the guideline is followed and that appropriate treatment is prescribed for the patient.
Introduction
Parkinson's disease is a progressive degenerative neurological disorder associated with loss of dopamine producing neurones in the substantia nigra.
The main features of Parkinson's disease are:
Slowness of movement;
Muscle rigidity;
Tremor;
Postural instability (later stages).
Parkinson's disease is a condition which affects movement and motor function but it is also a condition which causes many non-motor symptoms (depression, anxiety and pain).
Medication is crucial in optimising management of Parkinson's disease.
The patient's condition will deteriorate significantly if medication cannot be given.
Missed doses can put the patient at risk of neuroleptic malignant like syndrome.
The guideline provides information on alternative treatment options and method of administration when a solid oral dosage form cannot be administered via the oral route.
Each regimen must be reviewed on an individual basis with the intention of returning the patient back to their original oral regimen as soon as possible.
Initial Management of Patient's with Parkinson's Disease who are Nil by Mouth or who have Swallowing Difficulties
It is crucial to continue Parkinson's Disease medication as there is a risk of neuroleptic malignant like syndrome.
Ensure accurate medication reconciliation and that medication is correctly prescribed.
Assess patient's swallow early and ensure provision of medication via alternative route ASAP if any concerns.
(Refer to Appendix 1 for management algorithm)

Each patient must be reviewed on an individual basis. A review should be completed every 24 hours with the aim of reverting the patient back to their original regimen of oral medications as soon as possible.
Check contra-indicated medication is NOT prescribed.
Risks of Omitting Parkinson's Medication
Deterioration of swallow – higher than normal risk of aspiration and aspiration pneumonia.
Exacerbation of Parkinson's symptoms – motor (mobility, self-care, falls risk) and non-motor (pain, anxiety, lack of concentration and focus, slowness of thought).
Deterioration in longer term Parkinson's control – can result permanent reduction in mobility.
Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome – pyrexia, fever, confusion, raised CPK, muscle rigidity, altered consciousness.
Death – patients with Parkinson's have greater in-hospital mortality. Ensuring patients receive their usual medication and timely specialist review will reduce this risk.
Management of complications associated with Parkinson's Disease
Delirium:
Avoid typical antipsychotics which are contraindicated and may worsen motor symptoms;
Use lorazepam first line in an acute phase of delirium or acute confusion. If longer term treatment is indicated consider atypical antipsychotics;
Avoid risperidone and olanzapine as they may have a higher risk of worsening Parkinon's;
Ensure patient not on any anti-cholinergic medication (which can worsen delirium).
Lower respiratory tract infection:
Early physiotherapy, sitting out and mobilisation.
Constipation:
Constipation will affect medication absorption;
Treat aggressively with macrogol laxative;
Ensure adequate hydration.
Urinary Tract Infection:
Ensure adequate hydration;
Consider community-based anticipatory for future management if cause of recurrent admissions.
Orthostatic hypotension:
Ensure adequate hydration and salt intake;
Rationalise anti-hypertensive medication;
Consider compression hosiery (if not contra-indicated);
Consider fludrocortisone.
High falls risk:
Treat any underlying orthostatic hypotension;
Ensure early physio review;
Consider bone health.
Contra-indicated Medications in Parkinson's Disease
Typical antipsychotics.
Centrally acting anti-emetics (metoclopramide, cyclizine, prochlorperazine) can worse Parkinson's Disease.
Anti-cholinergics can worsen confusion.
Pharmacy – Supplies/ Stock Location
During working hours patient's medication can be ordered from Pharmacy.
Out of hours Emergency Parkinson's medication can be obtained from the Parkinson's
shelf in ED Majors. Speak to the Nurse in Charge about accessing this medication. (Refer to Appendix 2 for the list of medications which are stocked here).
Useful Contact details
Parkinson's Disease Clinical Specialists on extension 4438.
Medicines Information on extension 4822.
On-call pharmacist (out of hours) via switchboard.
Staff and Training Requirements
All medical and nursing staff are to ensure that their knowledge, competencies and skills are up to date.
During induction, staff will receive instruction on current policies and guidelines and how to access them.
On approval by the Document Ratification Group (DRAG) this guideline will be uploaded to the Trust Intranet.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix 3)
Audit and Monitoring

Pharmacy will review prescriptions of patients with Parkinson's Disease during routine ward visits and when reviewing charts in dispensary. Any concerns will be reported to the physician responsible for the patient.
References
NICE Guideline CG35
SIGN 113 Diagnosis and pharmacological management of Parkinson's disease. January 2010
NICE – National cost-impact report
Parkinson's UK. “Get it on time” campaign. www.parkinsons.org.uk/about_us/policy_and_campaigns- 1/campaigns/get_it_on_time_campaign.aspx
Reid J. Acute management of Parkinson's disease (Clinical guidelines). Fife Parkinson's Service 2011
Goff A, Jackson S. Parkinson's UK Patient Survey and Medicines' Management Audit in The Royal Devon and Exeter Hospital, UK, 2011. Parkinsonism and Related Disorders. January 2012. 2.225
Pepper PV, Goldstein MK. Postoperative complications in Parkinson's disease. JAGS 1999;47:967-972
Brennan KA, Genever RW. Managing Parkinson's disease during surgery. BMJ 2010; 341:990-993
Galvez-Jiminez N, Land AE. The perioperative management of Parkinson's disease revisited. Neurol Clin N America 2004; 22:367-377
Patel SG et al. How should Parkinson's disease be managed perioperatively? The Hospitalist 2012
Wullner U et al. Transdermal rotigotine for the perioperative management of Parkinson's disease. J Neural Transm 2010; 117:855-85
Han-Joon K et al. Overnight switch from ropinorole to transdermal rotigotine patch in patients with Parkinson's disease. BMC Neurology 2011; 11:100
Fox, Naomi. “Development of the OPTIMAL online guideline and calculator for Parkinson's medication in inpatients”, PD Academy Masterclass Newsletter - Moving On
Table 1: Management of Parkinson's disease patients with swallowing difficulties or feeding tubes in situ

table_items.text: Co-Beneldopa (any dose) is equivalent to Co-beneldopa Dispersible
Keeping the same total daily levodopa dose convert to dispersible tablets. The frequency may need to be altered.
Madopar CR 125 ON would be changed to Co-Beneldopa dispersible 125 ON
Continue current regime – plain release tablets will disperse in water OR switch to equivalent levodopa dose of dispersible Co-Beneldopa
Co-Careldopa (any dose) is equivalent to Co-beneldopa Dispersible
Keeping the same total daily levodopa dose convert to dispersible tablets OR switch to equivalent levodopa dose of dispersible Co- Beneldopa divided in 3 or more daily doses.
Continue current regime, plain release tablets will disperse in 15- 30mL of water.
Convert to plain release tablets. Covert to TDS regime.
Pramipexole MR 2.1mg OD would be changed to Pramipexole 0.7mg TDS
Continue current regime, plain release tablets will disperse in 10mL of water.
Convert to plain release tablets. Convert total daily dose to TDS regime.
Ropinirole XL 24mg OD would be changed to Ropinirole 8mg TDS
Continue current regime, plain release tablets will disperse in 15- 30mL of water.
Continue current regime, plain release tablets will disperse in 15- 30mL of water.
1.25mg of orodispersible tablets is equivalent to 10mg standard tablet
Continue current regime. Place tablet in an oral syringe and add
The Entacapone component can be safely omitted from
10ml of water. It will disperse slowly. The dispersion will stain and therefore crushing tablets to a dry powder should be avoided

Continue current regime but consider changing prescription to individual components (Co-Careldopa + Entacapone) – see above for further details. If NG tube switch Co-Careldopa to dispersible Co-beneldopa.
Stalevo 100 OD could be converted to Madopar Dispersible 125 OD.
Continue current regime, capsules can be opened and contents will dissolve in water

data.text: Table 2: Rotigotine conversion table if only on levodopa (with or without
COMT inhibitor) preparation
Caution needs to be exercised as it can cause nausea, vomiting, skin reaction, hypotension, hallucinations and increased confusion.
Caution and lower doses are required in patients with dementia/ delirium
Once commenced on the patch the strength needs to be monitored on a regular basis – consider putting the patient back on usual drug regime at the earliest available opportunity
Maximum dose of Rotigotine is 16mg/24 hours
Do not cut patches to achieve the correct dose
Caution and lower doses are required in patients with dementia/ delirium
Table 3: Switching guidelines from a single oral dopamine agonist to Rotigotine transdermal patch
Maximum dose of Rotigotine is 16mg/24 hours
Do not cut patches to achieve the correct dose
Caution and lower doses are required in patients with dementia/ delirium
